WHAT 120 MILES OF DEL MAR ACTUALLY LOOKS LIKE

Hover over the profile to see where the climbs, chaos, and "why did I sign up for this" moments actually are.

Mile 50
Black Canyon (Zwartenberg)

Miles 50-65: 1,400+ foot dirt climb on steep sand and washboard surfaces. The field shatters here—going from hundreds to dozens. One pro described it as shaking them 'to the core.'

ZwartenbergWashboard fire road with steep sand sectionsArrives when legs are fresh enough to hurt
Mile 85
Sandy Bandy

Miles 85-95: Long, narrow, twisting sand always into strengthening headwinds. Multiple race leaders have flatted twice here and lost everything. Destroys equipment and morale.

Sandy BandyLong twisting sand sectorsAlways into strengthening headwinds
Mile 116
Double Peak (Muur van Dubbelberg)

Miles 116-130: The terminal exam. 4.5 miles, 1,800 feet gain, 8% average with 17-23% grades. Peter Stetina won 2024 by pulling clear on these pitches and soloing the final five miles.

Facts And History

Belgian Waffle Ride isn't a race—it's a character test

The Belgian Waffle Ride began as a marketing exercise in 2012 when Michael Marckx (MMX), then president of SPY Optic, invited 136 people to ride bikes on dirt roads through North County San Diego. Marckx brought diverse athletic credentials—UCI cyclocross pro license, professional triathlete competing alongside Mark Allen and Scott Tinley, marathon runner posting 2:40s at age 14. He wanted to create 'a 6-7-8-12 hour cyclocross race bracketed by Belgian waffles and Belgian ale,' mixing the cobbled brutality of Spring Classics with California's technical terrain. The origin story traces to childhood rebellion. Young Marckx took his road bike through dirt fields as a shortcut to school, passing eighth-grade bullies who yelled 'You can't ride that bike in the dirt.' His response: 'I just did.' BWR embodies this: it refuses the 'gravel race' label in favor of 'un-road,' mixes single-track with pavement, and rewards technical skill alongside fitness. The first event saw 118 of 136 finishers. Within three years, BWR had grown to 1,000+ participants. Today, the series spans multiple locations (California, Utah, North Carolina, British Columbia), but the original San Diego event—now based at Del Mar Polo Fields as of 2025—remains the flagship. The $50,000+ prize purse is the largest in one-day gravel racing, and the 40% DNF rate is nearly double Unbound's attrition. Marckx designed the course to expose riders who 'do the group rides that never do any work and then all of a sudden, they're there for the sprint.' BWR rewards those who can actually ride bikes, not just pedal them. Marckx speaks about transformation stories: 'I signed up for the Belgian Waffle Ride, and I haven't raced my bike in 30 years. And it literally transformed my body and my mindset.' These narratives drive him more than elite results. Fourteen editions in, BWR has become American gravel racing's technical standard.

The Experience

You roll out of Del Mar wedged into a nervous pack of riders, half of whom are over-biked and under-trained. The first hour feels almost polite. Then the field hits the first challenging sections and you start seeing people on the side of the road wrestling with mechanicals and broken spirits.

The middle third is pure accounting: calories, bottles, chain lube, and bad decisions. The race doesn't "start" so much as it quietly removes options until you're either riding alone into a crosswind, clinging to a group that's too strong, or sitting in a folding chair at a checkpoint trying to decide if you're the kind of person who goes back out into the dark.

Length

The Waffle varies from 106 to 146 miles depending on the year. The 2025 course was the shortest in event history due to venue relocation. Historical courses average 120-135 miles with 10,000-14,000 feet of climbing. Long enough to require actual endurance training but shorter than Unbound 200.

Technicality

BWR is a six-hour cyclocross race wearing gravel clothes. The course mixes single-track, sand, water crossings, rock gardens, and 20%+ grades. Your bike handling determines whether you finish. Tire choice matters. Low gearing is mandatory. If you've only ridden group rides on pavement, this will expose that.

Elevation

10,000+ feet of climbing spread across endless rollers. Black Canyon delivers sustained washboard climbing on steep sand. Double Peak hits you with 1,800 feet over 4.5 miles at mile 116-130. The relentless variety hurts more than single massive climbs. You don't get breaks.

Climate

April in San Diego County starts cool (50-55°F) under marine layer, burns off to 75°F inland by afternoon. The real problem is wind. April is the windiest month. Constant headwinds that strengthen throughout the day. Sandy Bandy always runs into headwind. UV is moderate but persistent.

Altitude

Sea level start rising to approximately 2,500 feet maximum. Zero altitude concerns. Your lungs aren't the problem here.

Adventure

The 'unroad' experience delivers variety for a local training ground turned race course. You'll cross water, navigate rock gardens, question tire choices, ride single-track through chaparral hills. Belgian-themed sector names add cultural texture. It lacks the remoteness of Unbound or the geographic novelty of Mid South, but the technical variety compensates.

Logistics

San Diego International Airport sits 17 miles from the venue—25 minutes without traffic. Del Mar offers excellent lodging ($150-300/night), quality restaurants, straightforward parking. The Friday Expo and packet pickup are well-organized. You'll pay California prices for California convenience.

Prestige

BWR California is one of gravel's original monuments and the only event successfully claiming 'un-road' identity. The $50,000+ prize purse attracts WorldTour talent. The 40% DNF rate creates exclusivity through attrition rather than lottery barriers. Within technical gravel racing, finishing the Waffle carries credibility.

Race Quality

Fourteen years of iteration show in every detail. The course delivers variety without feeling arbitrary. Nine fully-stocked feed zones, comprehensive marking with Belgian-themed sector names, Friday Expo with 75+ vendors, Belgian waffles and Lost Abbey ales at the finish. Polished production that works.

Experience

The race balances brutality with celebration. Mass start with pros puts amateurs in actual racing. The technical variety demands constant adaptation—you're problem-solving equipment, terrain, and energy management simultaneously. Post-race Belgian waffles and ale with fellow survivors hits right.

Community

BWR offers warmth but not intimacy. Large field (2,800 riders) and festival atmosphere create energy, but you won't get Mid South's personal touches or Unbound's collective ethos. The vibe skews toward SoCal cycling culture—equipment-focused, fitness-conscious, competitive. Friendly, professional, slightly distant.

Field Depth

The $50,000 prize purse pulls legitimate WorldTour talent. Matt Beers, Peter Stetina, Sofia Gomez Villafañe treat this as a priority race. The competitive field runs deep. Open registration means the back of the field includes undertrained optimists, contributing to that 40% DNF rate.

Value

Registration costs $195+ for the Waffle. Add San Diego flights ($300-600), lodging ($300-600), rental car ($150-200), and meals, and you're hitting $1,200-1,800 total. The race production quality justifies the entry fee. But this is expensive.

Expenses

Total weekend cost runs $1,200-1,800 minimum. San Diego lodging is expensive ($150-300/night), rental cars are necessary, restaurant carb-loading adds up. Silver lining: easy direct flights to SAN from most major cities.

Should You Race This?

Yes, if you have legitimate technical skills from cyclocross or mountain biking, can handle 12+ hour moving time, and want to test yourself against a course designed to expose weaknesses. The race rewards actual bike riding—handling rough descents, choosing correct lines through sand, managing energy across varied terrain. It's expensive and honest about your capabilities. Skip it if you're purely a power athlete with limited technical skills, have never ridden extended single-track or sand, or can't stomach California travel costs ($1,200-1,800 total). Also skip if you need grassroots intimacy—BWR offers professional production and competitive intensity, not community warmth.

Alternatives

Unbound 200 for maximum distance prestige without technical demands, Mid South for community warmth at lower cost, SBT GRVL for Colorado altitude climbing with better budget logistics, Leadville Trail 100 MTB for technical mountain terrain with even higher attrition.

◆ THE BLACK PILL

THAT 23% GRADE EXPOSES EVERYTHING

The 23% grade at mile 130 will expose every skipped core workout and every group ride you sat on. Physics doesn't negotiate.

Here's what it actually costs:

  • You'll spend $1,200-1,800 (registration, flights, lodging, rental car) for a race where 40% don't finish
  • Technical sections punish momentary lapses regardless of fitness—Karl Bordine lost a four-minute lead when his front wheel disappeared in sand
  • Equipment choices genuinely determine outcomes—tire pressure, gearing, and bike selection can make or break your day

BWR rewards actual bike riding over pure watts. The 40% DNF rate isn't a bug—it's validation that the course works as designed. If you're purely a power athlete with limited technical skills, this race will expose you. If you can handle varied terrain, choose correct lines, and manage energy across relentless variety, you'll finish. The course doesn't negotiate with training plans—it tests whether you can ride a bike when everything hurts.

Race Logistics

The unsexy details that decide your day

Getting There
  • Closest major airport: San Diego International Airport (SAN) – 17 miles from Del Mar Polo Fields venue, approximately 25 minutes without traffic. Major hub with direct flights from most US cities. Rental car recommended ($150-200 for weekend).
  • Transportation: Del Mar offers full spectrum lodging.
  • When to arrive: Plan to arrive 2-3 days early for travel, shakeout, and gear organization.
Staying There
  • Lodging: Del Mar offers full spectrum lodging. Premium options include Hilton San Diego/Del Mar ($171+/night), Fairmont Grand Del Mar (5-star luxury). Mid-range athlete-friendly: Residence Inn San Diego Del Mar (suites with kitchens), DoubleTree by Hilton. Budget strategy: Airbnb in Del Mar, Solana Beach, or Rancho Santa Fe for group lodging and shared carb-loading dinners. Expect $150-300/night depending on tier.
  • Food & groceries: Pre-race carb-loading at Il Fornaio (fresh pasta), Sammy's Woodfired Pizza, Jake's Del Mar (waterfront), or Sbicca Del Mar. Race morning offers complimentary Belgian waffle breakfast at venue starting 5:00 AM with coffee. Post-race: Belgian waffles, Lost Abbey ales, food trucks, and Gear Grinder Grill barbecue at finish.
  • Packet pickup: Strongly recommend Friday arrival for Expo packet pickup. Friday Expo runs with 75+ vendors, gear demos, and packet pickup. Avoid race-morning pickup—very hectic with long lines causing missed starts. Saturday evening packet pickup also available but creates tight timeline.
  • Parking: Available at Del Mar Polo Fields/Surf Sports Park. Arrive by 5 AM for breakfast. RV camping available at Del Mar Fairgrounds via camplife.com.
